pros: Excellent coworkers, annual bonus, annual pay increase, growing company, tries to continuously improve themselves, decent sick/vacation time, manufacturing shutdowns during 4th of July weekend and from Christmas Eve through New Year's Day.
cons: Low pay, extreme bias by management, poor work/life balance, expected to do more with fewer resources, frugal with maintenance if it inhibits profit, overwork employees, doesn't appreciate going above and beyond, biased management, little accountability, little opportunity for advancement, interviewing process takes 2+ months (even for internal candidates), do not keep promises/deadlines, does not seem to care about employees, treat employees as if they are owned by the company, loss of benefits when converted from Life Technologies to Thermo Fisher, constantly uses the phrase "this is how we have always done it", doesn't listen to employees, poor utilization of employee resources

pros: Good place to work, lots of good people and good products.  Products are aimed at the clinical market, so helping to diagnose disease and keep people healthy.  Very fast pace, but keeps it very interesting and never a boring day.  In general, corporate management is good and they do try to take care of their employees.
cons: There are some in management who are only out for themselves, but this is everywhere.  In the Microbiology division, main problem is UK management of the US division.  They are clueless in how to manage their own division, let alone how they should manage an American division which operates in a health system very different than that found in the UK and Europe.  The management team is often not around for more than a year or two or three at the most.  Sometimes they move up within Thermo Fisher, but often they move out, sometime on their own volition, but often pushed out.

review_title: Every Thermo Fisher Site is Different
pros: Overall, the company is a powerhouse.  You will be a part of a monopoly-type company that will continue to grow while absorbing it's smaller competitors.  Careers can be built here, and the positions are long term and safe.
cons: As stated in the title, every Thermo Fisher Site is operated independently.  My review is for my specific site in Fremont, California.  Here at this site, the company grew too fast and the business model and technology could not keep up with the growth.  Since the site is operating at a pre-historic pace, while trying to keep up with the industry expectations, this results in long stressful hours and absolutely no work/life balance.  To top it off, the salaries do not compete with the current market, but i do hear that management is trying to adjust accordingly based off the current market.

pros: The only plus I have is the salary.
cons: Negative company culture, lots of turnover and sickness.

review_title: An improving place to have a career.
job_title: A Bit Too Unique to Guarantee Confidentiality in Houston, TX
pros: TMO has an evolving environment and the corporate structure is being established since the merger of Thermo and Fisher Scientific. Each site has profit / loss responsibility and they roll-up the values within each division and group. This evolving structure has had some issues with people in the wrong positions but will eventually get it done right.
cons: Decision-making is a complex task as each site has their own way of doing things. The new corporate structure has made this both easier and also more complex as more people need to come to an agreement. There is a serious need to get better aligned to a single strategy and there is still a lot of entropy to do it the way we have always done it.

pros: Great benefits, team members truly work hard and have great skill, large company with many moving parts that may interest you if you're willing/able to move, reputable name in the industry.
cons: The pay is awful... Who "decelerates" commissions because you're not to a certain percentage to plan. It's so demotivating but is seen as a benefit...; no work from home capability; middle managers are inconsistent and some have very little experience managing large teams; developing and advancing your career internally is next to impossible if you want to stay in the same department; senior level management is a true good ole boys club. Everyone that works here at that level has worked here for years and years and only hire in their friends and colleagues that think just like them. They preach being an employer of choice but show no concern to change the real issues preventing Thermo Fisher Scientific from becoming an employer of choice.

pros:
Nice, low key, relaxing environment to work in every day.  Work is always "work" but working in a park like setting where everybody is casual and relaxed makes a big difference.  The location in Carlsbad actually includes a park, an opportunity to get outside in the sun during breaks.  Felt like working on a nice college campus and this contributes greatly to the overall feeling of going to work there everyday.

Generally uses state-of-the-art business platforms so this is a good place for upgrading your technological skills in the business world.  It is a paperless company.

Not a lot of perks, but lots of freedom to get out of the office and walk around outside, which may sound funny but is actually a HUGE perk in terms of getting through the work day and enjoying where you work.  I loved their beautiful park and campus and took full advantage of this while working there.
cons: They use a lot of contractors to keep costs down.  Not so easy to get a permanent position, but is still a very good way to upgrade and update your skills or learn new skills that will help you advance in your career.

pros: I can put something on my resume
cons: There is zero communication within the business, and it often falls on the lab. Schedules are chaotic, with turnaround times and expedites dominating the work to be done, which leaves large backlogs and disgruntled employees. Management is useless and despite communication, show very little willingness for change. Coworkers have been leaving left and right to escape, with no replacements and long wait times for approvals just to post a position, which leaves us highly understaffed. They dont want to hire people full time, even when contractors prove to have a great work ethic and strong drive. They also show resistance in promoting current employees, but will shovel on the responsibilities and workload of 2-3 people into one in order to save money. The building is falling apart, and all "fixes" are purely cosmetic. Benefits have gone down with the price going up, PTO got slashed, we are on average paid less than other sites within the same company in the same areas and IT is impossible to work with. The Cincinnati "Patheon, a part of ThermoFisher" site a dead end company to work for, and I would highly recommend looking anywhere else to keep your sanity intact.

review_title: Rewarding and fulfilling software development experience with ET India
pros:

review_title: The good days are gone and the new regime is taking over. Sad to say, but it could be going downhill

review_title: Good place to start, but not one to finish
job_title: Customer Service Specialist in Boston, MA
pros:

review_title: My skills have improved, but you will not be compensated fairly based on your work ethic.
job_title: Quality Control Technician I in Rockville, MD
pros: There's job stability as this company if you do your job and you're not stupid and you don't mess up. Bottom employees work well, only a small margin though. Most are idiots.
cons: Management often doesn't communicate well with the employees that are doing the real work and can make the important decisions; poor department communication; lazy employees that do not suffer any repercussions from management because management isn't involved; poor salaries.

job_title: Senior Research Associate in Carlsbad, CA
pros: Thermo acquired us.  Kept us as such for about a year.  Not necessarily the best thing but not the worst for everyone.

They cut a lot of very knowledgeable people and showed no decency about it.  It made me happy to leave.

job_title: Senior Test Technician in Austin, TX
pros: They best reasons to work for Thermo-Fisher Scientific was I thought a great organization to grow and retire from. Working there and seeing first hand it is not.
cons:

I enjoyed working with the seasoned staff that worked in the manufacturing area, that was short lived. They hired a new lead and that person ran those seasoned people off. review_title: Potentially the best company ever but----
job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Newport Coast, CA
pros: Dominating the world of laboratory equipment and supplies. Great pay and benefits. Hard to accomplish what they do but they do it with strict controls over their people. It's admirable. Very intellectually stimulating environment if you have the tenacity to take it on.
cons:
They do not offer the sales representatives the support they need to the daily paperwork. No support for filling out forms or proposals. If you land to big an account, they will take it direct to keep you from getting the big commissions and then they raise your quota next year and take that account direct. Some managers have very bad reputations for being ruthlessly intimidating and threatening if you can't make your numbers.
Being a public traded company, the bottom line is tantamount to upper management who get serious monies for their efforts.

pros:
-intensity: fast-paced environment, constant multi-tasking
-colleagues: I have met some great, supportive people here
cons:

-Stress: As a young person in their 20s, I feel my health suffering from this job. The stress and lack of time for exercise, personal care, and mental health have definitely shaved off multiple years from my life.

-Site: I work in Carlsbad and the site culture is terrible. There is no HR presence as far as site events or moral goes.  I know it's a huge site, but they make no effort and it's very obvious.

pros: Probably one of the best managed companies on the marketplace from a corporate standpoint; consistent share price growth, which is a reflection of YOY profitability. review_title: The experience for the first few years was wonderful and rewarding, management changed and respect and honesty left.
pros: great company with the right team and managers

pros:

review_title: Has grown too fast and too big - your just a number

review_title: All around,,, great place to work

review_title: Large company with matrix structure and opportunities

review_title: Mostly, a solid company to work for.

review_title: Great growth opportunities, if you want to move around
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Denver, CO
pros: Thermo Fisher really encourages managers to develop their employees into larger contributors, leaders, functional experts, etc.  If you're committed to the company, but not really sure where the right fit is, you can openly seek a new role elsewhere and your manager will most likely support it.
cons: The downside to the growth is that you will most likely have to relocate.  If you're open to it, you can bounce around the world.  But unless you're in one of the major footprint areas for the company (Waltham, MA; Pittsburgh, PA; or now Carlsbad, CA (formerly Life Technologies HQ)), then that next opportunity means packing your bags.  Some people love it, others feel trapped - you typically commit to a couple years in the new location in return for relo assistance, but then you're likely to be asked to move again, once you're seen as a 'team player.'  There can be a fair amount of pressure on relocation.

pros: Work variety, friendly production staff
cons:
Management need to work big time on keeping employees who are great & committed to the company. 
Invest time in proper training.
High staff turn over
Unrealistic expectations 
Felt as though there are set rules for particular sections compared to others.
Investigate issues properly with evidence instead of here-say.
When employees approach management they push blame on others
Management only held people accountable when it suited them
Clique mentality, if you didn't fit in you weren't thought of.
No career development 
HR are very unprofessional,
Turning a blind eye if it meant more work for them.
Updating policies after serious incidents happening to cover themselves
Sacking people is their forte! 
8 people in a month! Many being fabulous workers!
I absolutely loved my job, I put in so much hard work & suggestions for money saving and production process. but it has completely gone down hill since management ejected 2 employees at once who kept the whole place in line. Now it's being run into the ground.

pros: Thermo Fisher Scientific could be a wonderful place to work.  They employ hardworking dedicated individuals who continually strive to promote a positive work environment.  Also, TFS offers a fairly decent benefits package with generous vacation compared to other larger companies.

Management is completely oblivious to the job functions of their employees yet continually change their SOP's without ever consulting the employee to see how this may interfere with their current job requirements!  If you work for TFS you will be overworked and under payed.  You will do what they say, when they say, and how they say.  Their is no work/home balance.  The rules WILL change without notice and you WILL be penalized!!!

job_title: Facilities Manager in South San Francisco, CA

job_title: QC Chemist in Fair Lawn, NJ

review_title: A place with huge potential that is low on resource and high on bureaucracy.
job_title: Manager In R&D in Rochester, NY
pros: Great brands, great connections to customers. Corporate office seem to be doing the right things. Products have huge potential for improvements.
cons: Consumable Divisions are short sighted, lack experienced leadership and are not resourced for growth.  Day to day factory issues take up marketing time. Middle management is reluctant to change, most have never worked outside of their roles and have no other experiences from other companies. Broken processes on top of a miss understanding of branding, product development and research. You don't want to stay long because the lack of change will kill your career.

review_title: Life Technologies days are gone, look elsewhere if you have the chance
pros: Some incredibly talented & bright scientists as peers. Good tools, nice meetings locations. Benefits are OK (private health & pension scheme); salary is OK.
cons: After being acquired by Thermo, a lot has changed with little clarity on the direction and vision for the future. It is an highly hierarchical, fixed-structure company, employees are viewed as numbers, HR serve higher management directly but put a show that they serve the employees. Co-workers relationships are on average based on competitiveness & very little empathy. Goes without saying that many managers worry more about their hierarchical position and reputation than anything else and here flattery and looking smart (rather than producing smart) will get you places. Also work-life balance & proper training is close to zero. Workload is, given headcount variation and other factors, unmanageable and you are told to focus and prioritise everything! A funny remark is that many projects are completed as DIY, I mean, there is no guidance, training or support from management yet results are demanded and yes there will be certainly yelling. I also have witnessed lack of respect and rude communications frequently. All in all, it is a quite toxic environment!

pros: At least it's a paycheck.

If you do your current job well, they don't want to let you move to another position or promote you as this would cost them more money.  The stress and pressure in the lab are through the roof because they are a contract manufacturer.  Their only concern is how much product they can get out the door to make money.  With the transition to Thermo Fisher, the benefits went downhill.  People lost paid time off and insurance went up with less benefits.  The fact that there are pages of job openings at the Cincinnati site shows how high the turn over rate really is.  The building is falling apart around their ears and people are trying to get out quicker than rats in a fire.

review_title: Criminally Low Salary; No Upward Advancement
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA

pros: I enjoyed my job, work-life balance, the compensation, facilities, my co-workers, company culture, and the company in general.

I heard a lot of criticism about my work and performance but little to no praise for it. First example, my manager was out sick for a couple of days. On my initiative, I posted a large note outside her cube to let people know. When my manager came back in, she was flabbergasted that I had done such a thing. Yes, she used the word, flabbergasted. She chewed me out for about 10 minutes. She claims that she told me not to do that before, but I do not remember the conversation. Second example, my manager called my work on an operator manual a failure. Yes, she used the word, failure. She pointed out specifics. I pointed out some things I did correctly in the document, but that did not seem to matter to her. When I asked my manager why I did not receive any compliments from her about my work, she did offer one, but I have not heard another compliment since.

I did not feel that I contributed to the company much. For example, my manager read and provided feedback on everything I wrote including some of my email messages. Although her feedback was valuable and improved the documents, I feel that things might have gone faster if she simply did the work herself. She often complained about how much time she spent redlining my work.

I did not feel that I was allowed to think for myself or take initiative in solving problems. For example, my manager asked me to resolve a conflicted files problem in our software versioning and revision control system. I asked a co-worker to help me, and we spent some time on the phone to resolve it. He seemed happy to help me, and we solved it. Afterwards, my manager told me not to waste his time and that every work-related problem I have should go through her first. She also called that co-worker to apologize to him for wasting his time, which I did not feel was necessary.

review_title: Good place to work for people who don't get frustrated too easily
job_title: Project Support Associate in Horsham, England
pros: Good career progression and staff development for those who want it; lots of regular 'fun' activities eg. Bake Off competitions, twice yearly themed staff picnic events onsite; most people who work there are very nice; senior management very approachable and friendly
cons: Location - quite remote and cannot be reached by public transport and also right next door to a very smelly landfill site; office space is claustrophobic (large open plan office with no windows); inequalities in salary amongst people doing the same work; very rigid processes which can make it frustrating to get work completed; working at home outside of core hours is often necessary in order to keep on top of work load (see previous comment)

pros: Competitive salary and benefits package attracts a competent talent pool. Opportunities to work remotely offer flexibility for work-life balance.
cons: Small pockets of the company drive execution and strategy for multiple divisions, which leads to breakdowns in documenting requirements for projects, establishing appropriate measures of success and mapping realistic project timelines. While the company attracts some of the best and brightest in terms of talent, that same talent pool is prevented from using their skill sets to their greatest advantage when decisions are driven by so few without seeking input from the pool of talent across the organization. Ultimately, this contributes to lower individual job satisfaction and higher than average turnover rates.

pros:
My years with Thermo Fisher Scientific undoubtedly have been among the greatest experiences of my profession.  I left the position having gained not only a well-versed expanse of knowledge in finance but also corporate strategies of all levels. 
I am pleased to be able to state on my resume that I worked with Thermo Fisher Scientific for ten years. Their global recognized status puts me in an advanced skilled level.
cons: This company is understaffed and as a result employee's are working extremely long overtime on a regular basis. This creates a environment where errors are made due to work overload and stress.

pros: The benefits are really great:  3 weeks of PTO, Many options of insurance plans, Good 401k, life insurance, short and long term disability.

The culture of the company is pretty much trying to find a guilty when something goes wrong.

Upper management does not hear lower level and understand problems and what needs to be done for things to be more functional and easier.
Lower management does not understand the job and their own departments processes and try to put in place processes that just do not work.

job_title: Regional Site Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: In my experience, Thermo Fisher pays well, supports employees to a reasonable degree, and shows loyalty to its employees. Upward mobility is encouraged and managers will hire within the company whenever possible.

But that being said,  I only had to make minor adjustments to make this work.

review_title: A fine company to work for

review_title: Surprisingly laid back work environment but not much money for Boston.

pros: Big. They've managed to buy out every scientific tools company that ever had a bad few years/quarters, so have cornered many markets and left customers with no choice but to buy from Thermo. job_title: Associate Manufacturing Technician in Grand Island, NY

-There are allotted volunteer hours, if small. And donation-matching for certain charitable efforts.

-TFS still pays below the median in Pittsburgh and it will only be more evident as larger and more progressive companies come to the area. Having good health insurance is great and I am grateful, but it isn't as attractive to younger employee that is trying to build their life and pay their student loans.

Pittsburgh's budding metro area will only propel young professionals to have a lifestyle without a vehicle and look elsewhere.

There is animosity between those employees whose work is considered more transactional and those whose work is considered analytical. The push is to consolidate the transactional work without really thinking or validating that those employees are producing the majority of the viable results. They say they're a family friendly and flexible company but there are quite a few departments that do not allow for flexible work schedules and working with Director and Vice President levels of management usually require meetings before and after normal working hours which impede on a work-life balance. Little to no bonuses for finance staff unless they are in corporate positions (not all business division have similar compensation packages). Heavy emphasis for finance team to program new reporting without the support of an IT team which results in a lot of different business systems that do not always translate or parallel report well across the business. review_title: Plenty of opportunity if you want it
job_title: Process Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Overall I have had an excellent experience at Thermo Fisher.  When I was hired I felt insecure after a recent layoff at my previous company.  Thermo Fisher has offered me tremendous opportunities for growth, which I took advantage of, and I am now leaving to go to graduate school armed with greater confidence and many more skills.

Some highlights:
1. Mentorship and interaction with executives - Directors and VPs were readily accessible and open to my questions about how their business worked
2. Education outside of Thermo Fisher - they sponsored several expensive graduate courses at Stanford, in addition to offering many other employee training opportunities
3. Access to new challenges - I consistently felt supported and challenged in my roles, and my previous managers wrote excellent letters of recommendation for me which helped me get into a competitive graduate program
4. Opportunities for advancement - in my first role, it wasn't obvious what my next job would be if I sought a promotion, but it's such a large organization, that there are opportunities everywhere.   I think they make a significant effort to promote from within.
5. Work life balance - I worked in San Jose and Sunnyvale and at both sites I thought the work life balance was good for "professional track" employees.  I did close to no work on weekends, and felt like my schedule was very flexible as long as I was achieving results.  Working from home was usually an option, unless there was work I needed to do in-person on the products themselves (I'm an engineer).
cons:
1. Culture - typical of many major corporations.  There's a significant amount of bureaucracy and it can be difficult to make changes even if the solutions are easy and obvious.  
2. Pay raises for hard workers - if you don't get promoted, your annual pay increase will be 1-2.5% MAX.  My manager told me once, "if you work hard, you'll get a 2% pay raise, if you work really hard, you'll get a 2.5% pay raise."  Which I didn't find very motivating.

Other managers I dealt with were petty, indecisive and didnt have a good grasp of the competitive landscape.  It felt like doing a lot of work for nothing most of the time as decision-making was slow and worse yet, ended up incorrect.  

Pay wasn't great, especially compared to what I have now.  Personally, I only give the level of effort that warrants my level of pay.  If you're talented at something, don't give it away for free or even at a discount.

For the high achievers - looking to learn and/or looking for better pay, this is definitely not the place.  Put it this way, the company were using obsolete Dell computers until July 2013. job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
First, bear in mind that what I say here only pertains to software development. Hardware, consumables, sales, etc are all entirely different animals. Also, the culture and environment within software varies radically from one site to another even within the same functional group.

That said, there is real job stability. The company makes money in spite of itself and it's nearly impossible to get fired. Work/life balance is not an issue. Most people barely work 40 hours a week.
cons:
1. The pay is relatively weak for the bay area. 
2. The technology is very outdated.
3. The organization is completely dysfunctional. Each software group (and there are many) is an island and they often go to war with each other.
4. There is no technical career progression path. It's just senior software engineer/architect -> manager, as if that makes any sense.
5. The management has no idea how to ship software. They keep making more and more process thinking that eventually if they add enough of it, they'll ship something. Spoiler alert: That doesn't work.
6. There are certain people who have been around since the dawn of time guarding the core code which prevents any real innovation being made. If you suggest anything new to them, they immediately dismiss it and claim that you don't understand the intricacies of reading and writing a flat file (that's seriously the tough challenge over here) when it's really they who are extremely slow on the uptake.
7. It doesn't matter how smart you are; the system here will crush any spirit of innovation you may have. You won't be able to overcome all the process and procedural hurdles necessary to implement any real new ideas. 

Really, San Jose is the worst place to be in Thermo software. It's a different story in the Informatics group in Pennsylvania and even in the Austin team, which is part of the same group as San Jose.

Be careful if you do not have a scientific background as the opportunities for promotion will be very limited.
cons: Pretty much everything done by management makes little to no business sense. The change was perceived by many sales reps as a slap in the face. Growth forecasts in one's territory can difficult to understand and for certain sectors such as government and academic territories are simple unrealistic. Management constantly shifts accounts between sales representatives with little to no explanation of why which confused customers and gave them a negative perception of Thermo Fisher's committment to their account. Often times this was done to r'ealign territories, or to help remove underperforming accounts from a poorly performing representative to a better performing reps territory. Thermo Fisher did not encourage work/life balance; more flexibility such as working from home should be considered. The office environment at Thermo Fisher has deteriorated due to high turnover, poor management, and constantly changing territories and expectations.

review_title: Big company with big changes due to acquisitions and consolidations of operations
pros: I am discussing Slide and Specialty Glass division in Portsmouth, NH. A lot of good science and good manufacturing. When the local company was left alone it provided a good training and growth opportunity through taking additional duties and challenges, including an effort on Practical Process Improvement which is similar to Six Sigma program. cons:
After acquisition by Thermo, the only things that seemed to matter were quarterly financial results. The precision system of people working together on average for over 20 years (and many for over 30 years!) was dismounted by bringing new General Manager first every two years and later every year. Each one wanted to bring his own people aboard and shuffled existing position which usually made no sense at all. After five years all the core personnel was gone and people who were newcomers brought just a year earlier were trying to teach newly hired, which of course wasn't effective. It seemed that all people with more experience (and a bit higher salary reflecting the experience) were systematically replaced by new ones which could be paid less due to their age, limited experience and current job market conditions. 
The company was a cash cow with big margins, dominating the saturated market of glass slides and similar products. Yet it was treated like many other divisions with growth potential and ordered to post big growth each year, which was completely unrealistic due to the shrinking of the market for such products. 
The financial pressure on all employees and continuous layoffs in sneaky ways of small numbers of people with no explanation to them or to the rest of workers created a horrible work environment.

review_title: Big company practicing big company shenanigans
pros: Good work/home life balance, good location.  There are a lot of good, hard working people there.  It is a clean factory and can serve you well as a first job or to get good experience for a couple years in any area.
cons:
Low pay, low level of support from management, too heavy on lean manufacturing, site management cares more about shipping product  than anything else, SAP implementation was a flop, left holes that may never be filled. There seems to be a trend of people whose job is to make work for others and take credit when it's finished; it's alarming that the number of people doing this is growing but the number of people to do the work is diminishing.  The ones who work and are reliable have work continually piled on them, making it nearly impossible to look good enough for a big raise or promotion.  People leave and aren't replaced, new product is brought in and no additional resources are given, a lot is expected and not much is rewarded.  
  Just a personal story, I was promoted to a department Administrator from within, my pay was structured on what I was making working in the factory and not what fair for the market, meaning they got me to do the job for significantly less than an external candidate with the same credentials. Since I was promoted 2 months before the annual raises, I was excluded from my raise that year, the next year I was given a whopping $.25 raise per hour, my manager reasoned that because I had such a big raise the previous year, I was fortunate to get a raise at all.  The experience was really discouraging.
  The manufacturing facility was Forma Scientific before being purchased by Thermo Fisher, and Forma had a reputation of treating employees well, paying them well, and being a great place to work. Sadly, that is not the case now, and even more sadly, it's not unique to this company.  The old Forma employees are topped out and haven't had a raise in years, new employees are doing work for $12/hour while they stand beside someone doing the same job who makes nearly $30/hr.  This situation also leads to employees with ambition and drive to be discouraged by those who are trying to ride the last few years out before retirement.
  I found there are 3 groups of people who work at Thermo in Marietta.  Those who are looking to leave, those who are looking to retire, and those who are too dumb to know any better.  I haven't found anybody who doesn't fit in one of those categories.
  Having said that, there really are a lot of good people working for Thermo in Marietta, if you are new to the workforce in engineering, welding, assembly, refrigeration, put in a year or two, then leave and go get paid like an adult, because God knows you won't get that here.

review_title: Not a High Tech Company - Not an Employee Friendly Company!
pros: False sense of security that comes from being in a large corporation.  Benefits and 401K match generally good but benefits keep getting more expensive and covers less.  Facilities are very nice and with lots of effort you can wrestle capital dollars out for your projects.  Have some good opportunities for students and interns.
cons: Employees are as disposable as paper towels!  I've witnessed age and disability discrimination aimed at people of all levels and tenure.  Company periodically does layoffs while advertising for similar jobs.  Management competence may be the worst in the USA!  Constantly putting people in high level technical management positions who have no technical training or experience.  Company is a caricature of all that is wrong with corporate America in the 21st century - quarterly meetings to tell employees of record profits, while last 3 years average raises were - 0.5%, 0%, & 1.0%!!  Attrition at my location is about 20% a year and senior, well trained folks are replaced with junior level (aka CHEAP) workers if they are replaced at all!  Product quality and margin drop year over year and there is no connection for management between staff competence and project success.  The CEO is one of the highest paid in the world while this is not one of the most profitable companies in the world.  The upper management ranks are staffed with those that went to school with the CEO (and not a good school!), and equity is only doled out to those in the "Club".  Most mid and low level managers have no equity at all.  The company makes acquisitions and after a couple of years drives off the valuable employees (who often go to start competitors) squeezes who is left, drops quality, kills margin, and eventually shuts the doors! The company strives to be listed as a highly desirable employee but the work experience is so spotty across the company that for everyone who is happy, there are ten who aren't.  Company expounds on "4 I" values while management embraces none of them in their practices.  Management puts lots of barriers up for getting work done such as giving little authority to individual location managers as exemplified by the ridiculously low dollar value of signature authority.  Most decisions and large purchases have to be run through headquarters. While capital is tightly regulated, expenses are not.  The corporation is very reluctant to invest capital in existing businesses and is much more attracted to acquisitions.  This is a very hard, cold, unappreciative, unrewarding place to work where few think their future will be better!

Pay starts out slightly below market, but them remains there since all bonuses are based on "unrealistic" stretch goals (you enter your stretch goal, and then it gets "upped" 10%).

There is a major disconnect between Products and Management.  This is culture based.  Focus is on money only and not on how to create the best product FOR the money.
Layoffs are a yearly or quarterly reality.  Often used to remove higher paid employees to trim bottom line (regardless of talent and contribution).

review_title: Stingy employer, treats all employees like a liability on the balance sheet.
pros: I worked at the Bothell site (formerly Advanced Microscopy Group) and generally speaking the technical team is quite competent.  If you are looking to gain some experience and can put up with the corporate idiocy , it's not a bad place to park yourself for a few years.
cons:
Unfortunately, not all teams are that competent, and Thermo has a problem with firing people.  We had the misfortune of having to work with some of the worst engineers I've encountered from their Pittsburgh facility - how these guys managed to ever ship a product, I have no idea. 

However, my biggest complains are along the line of how the company treats its own employees:

1)  I had a child during my career with Thermo Fisher.  Despite planning months ahead and putting in the paperwork for paternity (unpaid, FMLA) leave, HR decided to not grant it on the week my son was due.  They refused to grant FMLA leave until the child actually arrived.  My child arrived 2 weeks late, so during the 2 weeks leading up to the child birth every few days I had a fun call with a droid in Human Resources asking if I want to use up my sick time, my vacation time or come back to work leaving a pregnant wife that couldn't drive herself anywhere for her medical checkups.  As a result, my son came into this world with me not having any sick time left to care for him if he was sick.  

2)  HR would tell you that the vacation policy is inline with what is offered in industry.  What they don't tell you is that A) they combined sick and vacation days into a single PTO pool, and in the process most people with any sort of seniority lost "time off".  Secondly, this PTO pool is very difficult to use thanks to all the rules added in.  It is wiped clean at the beginning of the year and granted in 1/12 increments at the end of the month - so your December vacation allotment is granted on Dec 31st and wiped off the balance on Jan 1st.  To "graciously" allow you to use your earned vacation days, HR allows you to go up to -40 hrs on the PTO balance.  Rounding errors and such would make it hard to take all the vacation days and also it precludes the ability to take any decent vacation for the first half of the year.

3)  I've since found better employment at greener pastures, and shortly after handing in my resignation I received a letter notifying me that our family's (lousy) health insurance coverage will terminate at midnight the day I walk out the door.  Every job I've had up to this point covers you until the end of the month (since the deductions from my paycheck had paid for them till the end of the month).

They wonder why 50%+ of the staff say that they'd rather work somewhere else for the same pay, and installed a pop corn machine.  Too little, too late...
